summary: This study addresses the high mortality rates among African Americans due to complications from uncontrolled hypertension. It investigates whether a faith-based self-management education program can enhance self-care practices related to hypertension management in this demographic. The research involved ten African American adults with a hypertension diagnosis of at least six months who participated in an eight-week program designed to teach management strategies. The program uniquely integrated spiritual practices such as prayer, Scripture reading, and journaling to support participants in managing their health effectively.
reasoning: The summary captures the essence of the research by highlighting the problem of hypertension among African Americans, the aim of the study, the participant demographic, and the unique elements of the educational program. It avoids detailing specific methodologies or processes, focusing instead on the overall goal and context of the research.
